He plans to install it within two weeks of delivery. This is his sixth loan with SMEP DTM; he managed to pay off his latest loan of KES 40,000 successfully. His business goal is to open a bakery within 5 years.  He also hopes that in the future he will expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase a water tank

loans.name: Pascasie

texts.en:
Pascasie is 33 years old. She is married to a constructor. They both have four children who all go to school. 

She sells foodstuffs and has been in that business for five years. With the loan, she wants to buy more foodstuffs such as potatoes, rice and bananas for sale. 

The profits from the business will be used to renovate the house.

loans.use: to buy more potatoes, rice and bananas for sale.

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is 38 years old and blessed with five children. He is a livestock trader and has been running the business for the past five years. He makes a monthly income of KES. 20,000.

He has borrowed his first loan of KES. 20,000 from KADET LTD. He intends to use the loan to purchase more livestock for resale. 

The anticipated profit will be reinvested to boost business. His future dreams is to improve his living standards.

loans.use: to purchase livestock for resale.

loans.name: Enver

texts.en:
Enver, 41, lives in the southern part of Kosovo. He is married and has four children between the ages of eleven and seventeen years old. 

Enver used to live in Germany, and now he receives a social pension from there and has moved back to Kosovo. For the moment, he is looking for a job, but it is very hard to find one. Since he has four children, it is very difficult for them to secure the basic things for living. 

Enver is requesting a loan in order to buy new doors and windows to prepare for wintertime. The loan will help them to have a better life with comfortable conditions. Enver hopes to offer a better education for his children. Enver and his family want to thank all Kiva lenders!

loans.use: to buy new doors and windows.

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.en:
Jeanne is 31 years old. She is married to a driver, and they both have three children who all go to school. 

She has a boutique that she has been running for three years. With the loan, she wants to add more rice, salt, sugar and soaps for sale. 

The profits from the business will be used to make more savings.

loans.use: to buy more rice, salt and sugar for sale.

loans.name: Rita

texts.es:
Rita de 61 años, convive con el padre de sus hijos, porque ellos ya dejaron el hogar. Su casa es propia y se ubica en un distrito rural de la selva central. Rita es una mujer que se esfuerza mucho por sus ideales, ya que a su edad continua laborando en la actividad que más le agrada. Cuando tenía 18 años inició sus labores en la agricultura. Al lado de su esposo han sabido labrar y cultivar la tierra, para producir. Los frutos que cuida son de café, kión, plátanos y paltas. “Me gusta producir de todo, así tengo ingresos para todo el año”, menciona.
Su centro de ventas se ubica a 20 minutos de su comunidad, por ello no tiene problemas en el traslado, más si es la inversión. Dice que los fertilizantes son lo más caro en su actividad, además del pago de la mano de obra, para los cultivos y cosechas. A pesar de todo ello, Rita continúa firme en su actividad. Ahora piensa plantar más café, para ello ya tiene un vivero listo. Ella requiere de bolsas de abono orgánico para esta labor. Solicita de su apoyo. Ella pertenece al banco comunal “Prestatarios de la unión palomar” y este es el tercer crédito con MFP, donde espera salir adelante con el apoyo de su banco comunal, los que trabajaran arduamente para salir adelante. Además promete ser puntual con el pago de sus cuotas.
Con el dinero podrá adquirir bolsas de abono orgánico para sus cultivos de café, plátanos y paltas.
texts.en:
Rita, 61, lives with the father of her children; her children have already all left home.  Her house is hers and it’s located in a rural district in the central jungle.  

Rita is a woman who strives hard for her ideals because at her age she continues working at what she likes best.  When she was 18, she started working in agriculture.  Alongside her husband, they’ve succeeded in tilling the soil and cultivating the land to produce.  The fruits she grows are coffee, ginger, bananas and avocadoes.  “I like to grow a bit of everything so that I can earn income year-round,” she mentions.  

Her sales point is located 20 minutes from her community so she doesn’t have any transportation problems but she does have them with regard to investment.  She says that fertilizers are the most expensive in her activity and so are labor costs during planting and harvesting.  Despite all this, Rita continues firm in her activity. She’s now planning to plant more coffee and has her nursery ready for this.  She needs bags of organic manure for this work and she’s asking for your support.

She belongs to the “Prestatarios de la Unión Palomar” (Palomar Union Borrowers) and this is the third MFP loan.  She hopes to get ahead with support from her communal bank who work hard to get ahead.  She promises to be punctual with her payments too.  She will be able to buy bags of organic manure for her coffee, banana and avocado crops with the money.

loans.use: to buy bags of organic manure.

loans.name: Kankelentigui Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq membres du groupe KANKELENTIGUI    sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans, et ont en moyenne  5 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogamiques au quartier Babemba un des nouveaux quartiers de la ville de Sikasso 3ème  région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur dixième prêt avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.
Mme Dounaba fait le commerce  des habits  dans ce groupe de femmes de  KANKELENTIGUI elle se tient en première position de  la gauche vers la droite. 
Elle compte acheter avec son prêt 15 pièces de pagne wax et 5 pièces de bazin  qu’elle revend en détail sur place en famille à une clientèle composée pour la majeur partie de femmes au comptant. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 87 500FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne .
texts.en: The five members of the Kankelentigui Group are married women with an average age of 39. They have an average of five children.  They mostly live in monogamous families in the Babemba area, one of the new neighborhoods in the city of Sikasso, the 3rd largest administrative region of Mali. In order to better satisfy their customers' needs, they are on their tenth loan with Soro Yiriwaso, the microfinance organization.  Ms. Dounaba sells clothing and she is the first person (from left to right) in the photo.  She plan to use her loan to buy 15 pieces of "pagne" fabric and five pieces of "bazin" fabric that she will resale retail for cash at her family home to a clientele of mostly women. She plans to earn an average monthly profit of 87,500 FCFA, which will be partially used to repay her loan and interest and partially saved.

loans.use: to buy clothing.

loans.name: Gurgen

texts.en: Gurgen lives with his wife and son in Sardarapat village, in the Armavir region.  He is 54 years old and has more than 30 years of experience in the agricultural field. He runs a farm where he grows 300 plum trees. As the operating costs of such a big farm are high Gurgen needs some capital to cover them; that’s why he has applied for this loan. With the requested amount he plans to purchase fertilizer and 350 plum saplings, which will significantly expand his farm and allow him to cover other operational costs.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and 350 plum saplings

loans.name: Liana

texts.en: Liana is a 25-year-old woman who lives in the Agarak region with her parents. She is the only breadwinner in the family. She runs a farm where she grows apricot, peach, blood orange, pomegranate and fig trees. She also keeps a cow, but has no capital to acquire more livestock; that’s why she has applied for this loan. With the requested amount Liana plans to purchase one more cow and a calf. This will increase her income and will give her an opportunity to expand the business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase one more cow and a calf

loans.name: Wakio

texts.en: Wakio is 27 years old and lives with her husband and three children. She is dedicated to her work as a shopkeeper, and has worked in her store for a year now. She began working with her parents and still does. The loan she needs is to resupply her store with groceries; she plans to buy food stuffs, basic grains, cleaning products, etc.  This will help her increase her income. Among her principal dreams is to have other stores and to be able to educate her children.

loans.use: to buy food stuffs, basic grains, cleaning products, etc.

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en: Hannah lives with her husband in the town of Samburu. She and her husband work from home. She works selling clothes that she makes, like shorts and girls’ dresses, and doing tailoring work. She works almost every day and has been doing so for two years. Hannah is requesting a loan to buy fabric at wholesale which she will use to make the clothes she sells. She will also buy supplies she needs like zippers, buttons and thread.  Hannah’s dream is to earn more income from the business during the end-of-year festivities, and to have more comfort.

loans.use: to buy fabric, zippers, buttons, and thread

loans.name: Mukony

texts.en:
Mukony is 35 years old, married and supports a family of six people. He has been a maize farmer for the last three years, earning a monthly income of 15,000 KES (Kenyan shillings). 

He is servicing a second loan of KES 30,000 from KADET, which he intends to use to purchase farm inputs. The anticipated profits will be used to diversify into sheep keeping. His future dream is to improve his financial stability.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is a resident of Kongowea, Kenya. He is a married businessman who carries out the transport of goods and people through a public service vehicle; this is a trade he has run for five years.
 
He learned of Milango from a friend two years ago and joined in order to access funds. He is applying for a loan of 104,750 Kenya shillings to service the vehicle. 

The only challenge in the business is the high cost of spare parts and fluctuating fuel prices, but Joseph is determined to carry out his operations well because he believes that it is from such a venture that he can provide for the basic needs of his family. His future ambition is to be able to purchase a larger public service vehicle.

loans.use: To service the vehicle.

loans.name: Elmer Noe

texts.es:
Elmer, vive con su esposa y cuatro hijos, él se dedica a la venta de plátanos, este negocio surge por la intensión de buscar una alternativa para proveer a su familia lo necesario, lo realiza desde hace dos años.
Solicita un préstamo para la compra de plátanos verdes, para mantener la suficiente cantidad en el negocio, esto le ayudara para mejorar sus ganancias debido a que tendrá la capacidad de vender a los clientes, Además tendrá la posibilidad de realizar la compra por mayoreo y a bajo precio.
Su aspiración es mejorar sus ingresos económicos a su familia, ya que esto le permitirá que la calidad de vida sea mejor.
texts.en:
Elmer lives with his wife and four children.  He makes a living selling bananas.  This business came about with the intention of finding an alternative for providing for his family's needs.  He has been doing it for two years.

He's requesting a loan to buy green bananas to keep a sufficient quantity in his business.  This will help him improve his profits because he'll be able to sell to his customers.  Also, it will be possible for him to buy wholesale at a low price.

His goal is to improve his family's income because this will allow their quality of life to be better.

loans.use: to buy green bananas

loans.name: Las Aguilas Group

texts.es:
Gina  es uno de los miembros del grupo Las Águilas

Gina tiene 26 años. Ella vive con su pareja y su hijo pequeño. Gina se dedica a la venta de dulces caseros, aprendió este oficio gracias a su mama que  le enseño a prepararlos, ya son 02 años que se dedica a este negocio y diariamente recorre diferentes lugares para ofrecer su producto, gracias a su empeño tiene muchos clientes esto le permite tener ingresos para ayudar con los gastos de la familia. Gina sueña con tener un negocio estable  en su casa, el préstamo que ha solicitado lo invertirá para la compra de  utensilios nuevos para mejorar la atención a sus clientes.
 ¡Gina agradece el apoyo de los inversores KIVA! Ella es la segunda de la izquierda esta parada y viste casaca azul.
texts.en:
Gina is a member of the communal bank " Las Águilas."

Gina is 26 years old, and she lives with her partner and her small son.  Gina has a business selling homemade sweets.  She learned this trade thanks to her mother, who taught her how to prepare them.  She's had this business for 2 years already, and she goes around daily to different places to offer her products for sale.  Thanks to her efforts, she has a lot of customers.  This allows her to have income to help with the family's expenses.  

Gina dreams of having a stable business in her home.  She will invest this loan in new utensils that will allow her to provide her customers with better service.  

Gina appreciates the support of the Kiva lenders!  She is the second from the left; she's standing and is wearing a blue jacket.

loans.use: to buy new utensils

loans.name: Abdullah Group

texts.en: This group is called Abdullah and consists of five women who live in Sana'a, Yemen. They applied for a loan of 200,000 YER from AMB. Saidh is a 41-year-old married woman with nine children. She owns a home and is a housewife who intends on working hard. Saidh is applying for a loan of 60,000 YER from AMB. She will use the loan to purchase construction supplies for her house. She hopes to improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase construction supplies for her house.

loans.name: Al-Mostafa Group

texts.en:
Al-Mostafa is a group which is comprised of 4 women and one man who are from Taiz, Yemen. They took a loan of 250,000 YER.

Rbab is 29 years old, married and has 3 children. She owns a house and would like to live in comfortable conditions. She is requesting a youth loan of 50,000 YER from AMB to buy construction supplies for her home. Her ambition is to have a farm to improve her living conditions. She hopes to own a car.

loans.use: to buy construction supplies for her home.

loans.name: Dubis Esther

texts.es: Dubis de 49 años, de edad se dedica a la confección de ropa, bolsos y al comercio en general, en su vivienda donde tiene su propio taller y un punto de ventas. En sus 27 años de experiencia Dubis  ha trabajado junto a su madre, quien la inició en el negocio de la modistería desde muy joven, hasta que ella misma logró comprar sus máquinas poco a poco, ponerse a trabajar sobre medidas y crear la clientela con la que hoy cuenta, la que cada día crece y esta es la razón por la que su capital de trabajo se muestra insuficiente para responder a la demanda del mercado. En su taller se realizan las operaciones de diseño, corte preparación, ensamble y acabado de piezas y también la comercialización de ellos en punto de venta, al que últimamente ha agregado artículos de miscelánea, para el hogar, papelería etc. Sus ventas las realiza principalmente de contado y sus compras también, en almacenes especializados en la ciudad de Barranquilla. En la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, tercer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará telas, e insumos de modistería y artículos navideños, aprovechando que la navidad se acerca y que su negocio debe estar muy bien surtido, para poder cumplir cabalmente su meta de crecimiento y ver finalmente a sus hijos convertidos en profesionales exitosos, tal y como los sueña.
texts.en:
Dubis is 49 years old, works making clothing and handbags, and also engages in general sales. She has her own workshop and sales location in her home. 

In her 27 years of experience, Dubis has worked with her mother, who got her started in the dressmaking business from a young age, until she herself managed to buy her machines little by little. She began working on custom clothing and building the clientele she now has, which grows each day. 

This is the reason why her working capital is proving insufficient to respond to market demand. In her workshop she does design work, cutting out, preparation, assembly and finishing of pieces, and also sells them at her shop. 

Recently at her shop, she has added miscellaneous articles for the home, stationery, etc. She sells and makes her purchases, mainly on a cash basis. She buys from specialized stores in the city of Barranquilla. 

Currently she is applying for credikiva loan, her third from the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. By means of the loan, she will buy fabric and dressmaking supplies, as well as Christmas articles, taking advantage of the fact that Christmas is approaching. Her business must be well supplied so that she can fully meet her goal of expanding, and eventually see her children become successful professionals, just as she dreams.

loans.use: To buy fabric, dressmaking supplies, and Christmas articles.

loans.name: Anusaya

texts.en:
Anusaya is a 32-year-old widow living with her three children who are in school. Her husband died four year ago from a heart attack. After his death, she was burdened with all her family responsibilities, so she started working as a daily laborer for a construction company but she was not satisfied doing it. After that, she started a small grocery shop in her village to take care of her children as well as earn some income. She sells spices, shampoos, bananas, detergents, soaps, oil, seasonal vegetables etc. in her variety shop.

She has a plan to increase her business by adding a few more products to her shop along with the existing products. She wants to keep toothbrushes, toothpaste, potatoes, wheat flour, grains, rice and other household consumables in her grocery shop.

She has requested a loan of 20,000 INR to make her shop bigger and add more products. 
. 
She has a dream of making her children study and not leaving their studies because of a financial crisis and saving some money for their future.

loans.use: to purchase toothbrushes, toothpaste, potatoes, wheat flour, grains, rice and other household consumables for her grocery shop.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel is 63 years old. He is married to a businesswoman, with whom he has three children aged 23 to 40. He sells foodstuffs; has been in the business for 25 years, and his wife helps him. With the loan, he wants to add more stock to his inventory of foodstuffs, such as beans and sorghum. The profits will be used for reinvesting in the business.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for sale.

loans.name: Francoise

texts.en: Francoise is 24 years old. She is married and blessed with two children. She sells shoes and has been in the business for 7 years. With the loan, she wants to buy more used shoes for sale. The profits from the business will be used for building her home.

loans.use: To buy more used shoes for sale.

loans.name: Robina

texts.en: Robina is 35 years old. She is married to a driver. They have three children, all of whom go to school. She sells sodas and has been in the business for 8 years. With the loan, she wants to buy more crates of soda for sale. The profits from the business will be used to build her home.

loans.use: To buy more sodas for sale.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice is 28. She is married to a businessman. They have 2 children aged 5 and 8, both of whom go to school. She sells maize flour, and has been in the business for 8 years. With the loan, she wants to purchase more maize flour for sale. The profits from the business will be used to renovate her house.

loans.use: To buy more maize flour for sale.

loans.name: William

texts.en: William is 32 years old and blessed with three children aged six, five and three respectively. For the past 3 years he has been a dairy farmer, making a monthly income of KES 16,000. He has taken his first loan of KES 10,000 from KADET LTD, which he intends to use to purchase an extra dairy cow. The anticipated profit will be reinvested to boost his business. His future dream is to improve his standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Narine

texts.en:
Narine is a 25-year-old mother of two children. She lives in Charentsavan town of Kotayk region. Narine earns her living by teaching school-aged children at her home. As it is difficult for Narine to sustain her family with her current income, she wants to find a new, profitable job. For this aim, she studies at the International Educational Center of the National Scientific Academy. She is taking her Masters Degree in the faculty of Economics. 

Narine has applied for this loan to pay for the tuition fee of the first semester. It is very important for her to pursue education, find a good job, and ensure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to pay her tuition, for the first semester of her Masters Degree in Economics.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase materials for making pastries

loans.name: Hadija

texts.en:
Hadija, 24, lives together with her husband and three children. She works buying and selling goats at the market. She also operates a kiosk from her home. She has been doing this for two years, and it has given her a lot of experience that allows to her earn more income.  She has a lot of customers.

Hadija is an active woman and a fighter, dedicated to her work. Every day she fights to make her dreams come true. She knows that only through perseverance and love of her work can she achieve success. She is asking for a loan to purchase more goats for selling.

loans.use: to purchase more goats to sell later.

loans.name: Angelique

texts.en: Angelique is 27 years old. She is married to a driver. She sells shoes and blouses for ladies and has been in that business for six years. With the loan, she wants to buy more shoes for sale. The profits from the business will be used to make more savings.

loans.use: To buy more shoes for sale.

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is a resident of the Kongowea area of Coast province, Kenya. He is married and owns a retail shop, a business that he has been running for four years. George began the business from a loan he obtained from a friend. 

He learned about Milango from other clients and joined the institution with an aim of accessing credit to improve the operations of his business. His main challenge is a lack of finances for expansion.
  
George is applying for a loan of 21,050 Kenya shillings to purchase additional stock of clothes. The extra income from the loan will be added to his savings to improve his living standards. He aspires to own a wholesale shop.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of clothes.

loans.name: Marion

texts.en:
This is 50-year-old Marion from Waterloo in the western rural area of Sierra Leone. She is married with four children between the ages of 20 and 33. Two of her children are currently going to school.

Marion runs a plastics business. She sells plastic buckets, cups and dishes at Waterloo. She has been running this business for 21 years. She works at the business every day, 12 hours per day.  She also receives income from her elder daughter. She says that the main challenges to her business are insufficient capital to run the business and price inflation.

Marion has requested a loan in order to buy more cooking stoves, plastic buckets, cups and dishes. The extra income from this loan will allow her to improve her standard of living and increase her business. In the future, she plans to build her own business structure. She appreciates your support.

video.title: Kiva Borrower Marion from Sierra Leone

loans.use: to buy more cooking stoves, plastic buckets, cups and dishes.

loans.name: Esheka

texts.en:
Meet 48-year-old Esheka from Waterloo in the western rural area of Sierra Leone. He is married with four children between the ages of 1 and 22. Two of his children are currently attending school. In 1988, Esheka established his general stock business within a busy market area. He began his  business because he needed to generate a permanent source of income to support his family. He works at the business from 7:00 am until 7:30 pm, 7 days per week. He says that the main challenge to his business is insufficient capital to run his business.  

Esheka requires a loan to buy more bags, sport T-shirts, and trousers. He hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow him to educate his children and improve his level of living. In the future, he plans to build a big house. He thanks you for your support.

video.title: Kiva Borrower Esheka from Sierra Leone

loans.use: to buy more bags, sport T-shirts, and trousers.

loans.name: Satrughan

texts.en:
Satrughan is a 26-year-old differently able man living with his parents and a younger brother. He is the only person earning an income in his family. He owns and manages a variety store from which he earns 4,000 INR per month. He sells betel, biscuits, toffees, wafers, tobacco sachets, face cream, talcum powder, soft drinks and hair oil in his variety store. 

He has a plan to make his shop bigger, add some more items like wheat flour, rice, spices, lentils etc. and renovate his shop. He says that by adding these items to his shop his monthly income will increase and he can make his family live a better and happier life.

He has requested a loan of 30,000 INR for purchasing more of the items he sells,and the above-mentioned products. 

He has a dream of making his parents live a happy life and building a house for them.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, rice, spices, lentils etc. and renovate his shop

loans.name: Swarnalata

texts.en:
Swarnalata is a 30-year-old widow who lives with her mother-in-law and her son. She has a small grocery shop in her house where she sells wheat flour, lentils, rice, edible oil, spices, salt, batteries and biscuits. She earns 2,000 INR per month from her shop, which is not enough for a family of three. She is the only one to support her family. 

She has requested a loan of 20,000 INR to purchase more stock of rice, lentils, oil, spices, etc. and add new product lines to her shop like cosmetics, hair oil, shampoo sachets, and detergents to meet her customers’ demands and make them highly satisfied. She hopes to build a separate shop outside her house and take good care of her son.

loans.use: to purchase rice, lentils, oil, spices, cosmetics, hair oil, shampoo sachets, and detergents.

loans.name: Rifadije

texts.en: Rifadije is thirty-one years old, married, and has four children, three of whom are currently attending school. The family lives in a small house in very poor condition. Rifadije is a housewife and her husband sells used shoes. They started to build another room on to the house but they can’t finish the work because of a lack of money. Rifadije is requesting a loan in order to buy building materials, doors and windows to finish the renovation so they can have more space for the children and a pleasant place for studying. She hopes in the future to have better conditions for her children! Rifadije and her family want to thank all Kiva lenders!

loans.use: To buy building materials, doors and windows

loans.name: God Bless Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, Northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present to you members of the “God Bless” group. These are small-scale entrepreneurs who have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to request a loan of 500,000 Sierra Leonean Leones each in order to invest in their respective businesses. 

Fatmata is the leader of this group. She is 39 years old, married and has 2 children; 1 is in primary school and the other is still not of school-going age. She sells ready-to-wear clothes and has been in this  business for 4 years now. With the help of this loan, Fatmata will invest in her business by buying ready-to-wear clothes in large quantity to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy ready-to-wear clothes in large quantity to add to her current stock

loans.name: Cecelia

texts.en: Cecelia is 42 years old, and a mother of three children. She is a mixed farmer and she has been in the business for the last five years. Her monthly income is KES 45,000. She is currently requesting her sixth loan of KES 70,000 from KADET LTD, which she will use to prepare the land and buy seedlings and fertilizers for use on her farm. She plans to use the anticipated profits to diversify into livestock farming. Her future dream is to improve the living standards of her family.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs and prepare the land

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is 59 years old, married to Eliud, and blessed with eight children. She has been practicing horticultural farming for the last 20 years, earning a monthly income of KES 18,000. She has applied for  a second loan from KADET LTD of KES 60,000 with which she plans to purchase farm inputs. The anticipated profits will be used to reinvest in the business and also provide for the family’s basic needs. Jane’s future dream is to improve her financial status.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en:
Mohammed, age 43, operates a spice store. He is a previous Kiva borrower and his business has benefited from his previous loan. His educational background is secondary school and he lives in Sana'a, Yemen. He is hard-working and determined and does not fear challenges. He and his wife have raised four children.

He has applied for a loan in the amount of 350000 YER from AMB in order to buy basic household goods such as sauces, beans, spices, seasoning, rice, cooking oil, and sugar with which to stock his business. He thanks Kiva for funding the first loan and is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to buy basic household goods such as sauces, beans, spices, seasoning, rice, cooking oil, and sugar for his business

loans.name: Al-Atmad Group

texts.en: This group, which is called Al-Atmad, consists of five women who live in Sana`a, Yemen. They applied for a loan of 180000 YER from AMB. Amadh is 32 years old and has 5 children. She has requested a loan of 50,000 YER to buy a new fridge. In the future, she would like to make more improvements to her home and to her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy a new fridge for personal use

loans.name: Nawal

texts.en:
Nawal is a 44-year-old married woman. She has seven daughters, two of whom are married, and two sons. Her husband works in a construction business to support the family.

Eight years ago, in order to help in supporting her husband, Nawal established a home-based daycare. During these eight years, she was able to move to another place to expand and have an independent daycare and kindergarten. Now she has applied for this loan to change the children’s uniforms and add more children’s seats and beds to be able to have more children.

No photo shooting was allowed in the kindergarten because of the privacy of the children, so a picture of Nawal was only taken.

loans.use: to change the children's uniforms and add more children's seats and beds.

loans.name: Al-Amtiaz Group

texts.en:
This group is called Al-Amtiaz and consists of four ladies who live in Sana`a, Yemen. They took out a loan of 260,000 YER from AMB.

Ashwaq is 24 years old, she is in good condition, but her income from sewing and selling traditional women’s clothes is not enough. She is asking for a youth loan of 70,000 YER to buy building materials to repair her house. In this way she will be able to offer her family a better quality of life and moral stability that will allow them to progress. Each month she will make her payment on time. She hopes to open a big sewing store.

loans.use: to buy building materials for her house

loans.name: Omm Maa Tarini Self Help Group

texts.en:
The Omm Maa Tarini Self Help Group is formed by ten members originally from the Bhadrak district of Odisha, India. These members are responsible married people. They have 23 children under their responsibility. They are all hardworking with hopes to self-improve. 

Basanti is the leader of the group. Her activity is a variety store located in her house. She sells basic products such as rice, beans, wheat flour, bread, eggs, sugar, tomatoes, potatoes and other household consumables. The lady wearing a red saree, standing third from the left hand side, is Basanti. This loan is needed for working capital to stock her store and satisfy the demand from her clients. Basanti, along with her group members, has requested a loan of 150,000 Indian rupees (INR) to enhance their businesses.

loans.use: to pay for purchasing products for her variety store such as rice, wheat flour, beans, bread, eggs, sugar, tomatoes, potatoes and other household consumables.

loans.name: Therese

texts.en:
Therese, aged 53, is widowed with seven children. Five of them attend schools. 

She owns a bar and has been running the business for 15 years. With the loan, she wants to buy more beer and sodas for sale. The profits from the business will be used to make more savings.

loans.use: to buy more beer and sodas for sale.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is 40 years old and married with six children, five of whom are in school and still young. He is in the brick making business. He works 6 hours a day, 6 days a week.

David will use the loan to hire laborers to burn his bricks because he expects many people to buy during this season. He will also put some money in tree planting because he requires wood for burning his bricks.

He hopes that in the future, with support, he can modernize the method of burning these bricks and also use modern ways of brick making instead of human labor, which is time consuming and expensive.

David's business faces several challenges. During rainy seasons his business is affected by weather. Also, sometimes there is high demand but he cannot produce enough to meet the demand. David says that with this money, he will employ many people to boost his performance in this business.

loans.use: to hire laborers for burning bricks.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is 28 years old and a mother of two children who are ages 9 and 3. She has run a beauty shop and salon business for the past 6 years, earning a monthly income of 40,000 Kenya shillings (KES).

She has applied for her first loan of 20,000 KES from KADET LTD, with which she intends to purchase additional hair products for resale.

She intends to use the profits gained to reinvest in and grow the business. Her future plan is for her business to become a large scale outlet.

loans.use: to purchase hair products for resale.

loans.name: Bujar

texts.en:
Bujar is 22 years old and married. He lives in a minority community in the southwestern part of Kosovo.

Bujar recently started his own business selling used shoes. He buys the used shoes and then he sells them in a market. He has a lot of customers who come to buy shoes. Bujar is very hardworking man who puts a lot of effort in his business. He is a main source of income for his family. 

Bujar is requesting a loan in order to purchase more used shoes at wholesale prices and then to resell them. The loan will help him to increase his profit. He hopes in the future to buy and sell more shoes and to expand his business. His goal is to save money and to have a better life. Knowing that this is a Kiva loan, he wants to thank all Kiva lenders for their support!

loans.use: to purchase used shoes.

loans.name: Shammy

texts.en:
Shammy is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kasese in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is married and has three children who are all currently in school. For the past five years, Shammy has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells fresh fish. 

To help expand her business, Shammy has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fresh fish for resale, and will help Shammy to generate greater profits and pay some of the school fees for her children. Shammy hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a vehicle. 

Shammy is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more fresh fish for resale.

loans.name: Pheginina

texts.en:
Pheginina is 24 years old and lives in the town of Kasese in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is married and has two children. For the past 3 years, Pheginina has been working hard to manage her small market stall that sells fresh food.

To help expand her business, Pheginina has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fresh food like matooke [steamed green banana, or plantain], sweet potatoes and cassava for resale and will help Pheginina to generate greater profits and pay for her medical expenses. Pheginina hopes that she will be able to build a big house for herself in the future.

Pheginina is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more fresh food like matooke, sweet potatoes and cassava for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a water tank.

loans.name: Leah

texts.en:
Leah is 29 years old, married, and a mother of five children aged between 2 and 10 years old. She earns her living through the buying and selling of green tea leaves and has been in operation for a period of 2 years, earning an income 2,000 Kenya shillings (KES).

She is servicing her second loan of 20,000 KES from KADET LTD after repaying the previous one successfully. She wishes to use this amount to purchase more fresh tea leaves from the local farmers.

She will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees for her school-going children. She hopes for a bright future.

loans.use: to purchase fresh tea leaves for resale.

loans.name: Manuela Ramos Group

texts.es: Buenas tardes, les presento el Grupo “Manuela Ramos” conformado por 07 socios que se dedican a diversas actividades de trabajo. Virginia tiene 48 años, casada y tiene 05 hijos. Ella se dedica hace 2 años a la venta de mercadería de ropa y calzado. Su sueño de Virginia es de ampliar y hacer crecer más su negocio para poder atender mejor a sus clientes. Virginia ha solicitado el préstamo para comprar ropas y calzados para implementar más en su negocio. El grupo  “Manuela Ramos” agradecen a Kiva y Edaprospo por el préstamo que les brinda y así poder crecer as en su negocio. Virginia está sentada del lado izquierdo, viste chompa color marrón y polo celeste.
texts.en:
Good afternoon, I introduce you to the group “Manuela Ramos".  It has seven members who work in a variety of areas.  

   Virginia is 48 years old, married, and has five children.  She has been selling clothing and footwear for two years.  Her dream is to expand her business so that she can better serve her customers.  She has requested this loan to further invest in her business with the purchase of clothing and footwear.
   
   The group “Manuela Ramos” is grateful to Kiva and Edaprospo for providing them the loan which allows them to expand their businesses.   

Virginia is seated on the left side, wearing a brown sweater and a blue shirt.

loans.use: to purchase clothing and footwear.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.es:
Gladys tiene 52 años, está casada con Aurelio. Ambos tienen una hija, Magaly de 17 años de edad. Ellos habitan un hogar propio ubicado en un anexo rural de la selva central. Gladys de apariencia frágil, es muy trabajadora. Su zona es propicia para brindar granos de buena calidad, sus tierras fértiles son adecuadas y buenas para brindar el grano de café con buen aroma. Es por ello que todos los fines de semana en compañía de su esposo cuidan de sus cultivos de café, ya tiene 16 años dedicándose a ello y según menciona sus granos son muy reconocidos en la cooperativa de Alto Palomar, donde vende en cada campaña agrícola. Cuenta que constantemente realiza viveros de café, con los cuales renuevan sus plantaciones antiguas, ahora tienen 3 mil plantitas en proceso de germinación; con ello esperan tener nuevos y mejores granos. Sus metas más próximas son atender sus cultivos, ya que el próximo año le espera una cosecha buena, porque confía en su esfuerzo, por eso requiere de su apoyo para adquirir lo necesario para que esto sea posible. Ella pertenece al banco comunal “Prestatarios de la unión palomar” y este es el segundo crédito con MFP, donde espera salir adelante con el apoyo de su banco comunal, los que trabajaran arduamente para salir adelante. 
Gladys con el dinero podrá pagar a los jornaleros que pagará para la limpieza de sus cultivos. Y con los 300 soles que calcula que le restaría, comprará bolsas de abono orgánico.
texts.en:
Gladys is 52 years old. She is married to Aurelio. Together they have one daughter, Magaly, who is 17. They live in their own home located in a rural annex of the central forest. Gladys is of fragile appearance but is very hard-working. Her zone is favorable for producing good quality coffee beans. Her fertile lands are appropriate and good for producing coffee with a good aroma. It is for that reason that every weekend she and her husband care for their coffee plantings. They have already been working at this for 16 years, and as mentioned their coffee is very well known in the Alto Palomar cooperative, where they sell their harvest each agricultural season. She comments that they always have a tree nursery, from which they renovate their older plantings. Now they have 3000 little plants in the process of germinating; with them they hope to have new and better coffee beans. Their nearest goals are to tend their plantings, since next year she hopes to have a good harvest, because she has confidence in their effort. For this, she needs support to acquire what is necessary so that this will be possible. 

She belongs to the communal bank "Prestatarios de la Unión Palomar" (Borrowers of Palomar Union), and this is her second loan with MFP, where she hopes to advance with the support of her communal bank, those who will work hard to advance.

With the money Gladys will be able to pay the day laborers to clean her plantings. And with the 300 PEN that she calculates will be left, she will buy bags of organic compost.

loans.use: to pay for labor and buy bags of organic compost

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en:
Mohammed lives in Ibb, Yemen with his ten children, whom he loves and who are his main reasons for living. He is very friendly, hardworking and enthusiastic, and he makes every effort to come out ahead. He has been selling vegtables and other foods. 

He collected a small amount to buy a rickshaw, but it is not sufficient to buy his transportation. So, he applied for a loan of 200,000 YER from AMB to buy a rickshaw for transportation. 

He hopes to open a retail store in the future.

loans.use: to buy a rickshaw for transportation.

loans.name: Rebeca

texts.en:
Rebeca, 35, is enterprising and responsible. She has always moved ahead thanks to her efforts. She lives with her family in the rural area of Samburu.

Rebeca runs her own business, where she sells clothes door to door. She is requesting a loan from Yehu so she can invest in more clothing in order to take advantage of the Christmas season, since that’s when most retailers’ sales increase significantly, which is a great advantage for Rebeca and others.

loans.use: to buy more clothing for resale.

loans.name: Laumes

texts.en:
Laumes is 23 years old and lives in the town of Kasese in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is single and has one child who is currently in school. For the past 3 years, Laumes has been working hard to manage her small market stall, in which she sells fresh food like matooke (green plantains, or a meal made when they are steamed).

To help expand her business, Laumes has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more sweet potatoes for resale, and will help Laumes generate greater profits and pay for some of the school facilities for her child, like exercise books. Laumes hopes that in the future she will be able to own her residential house. 

Laumes is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more sweet potatoes for resale.

loans.name: Chizi

texts.en: Chizi needs financing to supply her cereals sales business. It's thanks to her vegetable selling business that she has been equipped with entrepreneur skills. For this reason, she is requesting a new loan to be able to buy more cereals for sale. This will help improve her income and increase her customers. She says that she was able to cover her customers' demands with the previous loan, which helped to improve her financial stability.

loans.use: to buy more cereals for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase fruit, e.g., passions, lime, mangoes, etc.

loans.name: Las Nuevas Amigas Group

texts.es:
Sara  es uno de los miembros del grupo Las Nueva Amigas

Sara es soltera tiene 02 hijos de 10 y 05 años respectivamente, ambos asisten a la escuela. Ella es el único sustento de su hogar y empezó su negocio con la finalidad de generar ingresos para su familia. Sara se dedica al negocio de comidas, vende anticuchos  en un modulo que tiene ubicado en un centro comercial, son 03 años que lleva en el negocio y le va muy bien; su trabajo le toma 12 horas diarias; donde atiende aproximadamente a 60 comensales que acuden a su negocio. Sara se siente orgullosa porque su trabajo le permite solventar los estudios y las necesidades básicas  de sus hijos, con el dinero de su préstamo podrá ambientar su negocio y comprar más módulos para vender en otros lugares, gracias a los préstamos que EDAPROSPO le ha otorgado se ha superado mucho, su mayor sueño en la vida es tener una cadena de anticucherias y trabajar junto a sus hermanas,
¡Sara agradece el apoyo de los Inversionistas KIVA! Ella viste pantalón azulino y chompa negra.
texts.en:
Sara is one of the members of the group "Las Nuevas Amigas" (The New Friends). 

Sara is single and has two children, ages 10 and 5. Both are in school. She is the only support for her household, and she began her business with the goal of generating income for her family. Sara is in the food business. She sells "anticuchos" (skewered, grilled meat, usually beef hearts) from a stand that is located in a commercial center. She has been in this business for three years, and it is going very well for her. Her work takes her twelve hours a day, in which she serves approximately 60 diners who come to her business. Sara feels proud because her work allows her to pay for the education and basic needs of her children. With the money from the loan, she will be able to set up her business in other locations by buying more stands. Thanks to the loans that EDAPROSPO has granted her, she has overcome a lot. Her biggest dream in life is to have a chain of anticucho stands and work with her sisters. Sara is grateful for the support of the Kiva investors! She is wearing blue pants and a black sweater.

loans.use: to buy stands for her food business

loans.name: Serrina

texts.en:
Serrina is 33 years old and lives in Kakata Town. She is married and her husband is a businessman. She has five children ages 2 to 10 years old, all of whom live at home and are in school.

For the past 7 years, Serrina has been operating a little shop where she sells products like biscuits, soap, and soft drinks. She started this business with a loan from her mother. She enjoys her business because she has lot of customers.

She is requesting a loan to purchase more biscuits, soap, and soft drinks for her business. She plans to build a house in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase products such as biscuits, soap, and soft drinks for her business.

loans.name: Janiffer

texts.en:
Janiffer is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kasese in the Fortportal region of Uganda. For the past six years, Janiffer has been working hard to manage her small market stall where she sells fresh food such as matooke.

To help expand her business, Janiffer has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fresh food like matooke, sweet potatoes, and cassava to sell. This will help Janiffer to generate greater profits, allowing her to pay school fees for her young sister. Janiffer hopes that she will be able to buy a vehicle in the future.

Janiffer is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more fresh food like matooke, sweet potatoes, and cassava to sell

loans.name: Stanley

texts.en:
Stanley is a resident of Malindi, Kenya. He is a married father of two school-going children. He is a fisherman, a business he has run for five years. He also sells coconuts and other vegetables when they are in season. He learned about Milango from his friends.

Stanley is applying for a loan of 41,900 Kenya shillings (KES) to purchase a fishing net and a refrigerator. His main challenges include low seasons and the perishability of fish. He believes that the refrigerator will help store the fish.

Stanley will use the extra income from this loan to pay for his childrens' school fees. He has an ambition of being a wholesale seller of fish and other groceries. He also desires to buy a boat, which will help in fishing in large scale and be able to supply fish to hotels.

loans.use: To purchase a fishing net and a refrigerator.

loans.name: Fansta's Group

texts.en:
Fansta's group is composed of two hardworking women. Fansta is 21 years old and lives in the town of Hima in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is married and has three children, of whom two are currently in school. For the past 3 years, Fansta has been working hard to manage her small market stall, in which she sells fresh food like matooke (green plantains, or a meal made when they are steamed).

To help expand her business, Fansta has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fresh food like matooke, sweet potatoes, and cassava for resale. This will help Fansta to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children and to pay for medical bills. Fansta hopes that in the future she will be able to educate her children up to university level and also to buy a plot of land. 

Fansta is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more fresh food like matooke, sweet potatoes, and cassava for resale.

loans.name: Penina

texts.en:
Penina is 18 years old and lives in the town of Hima in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past 2 years, Penina has been working hard to manage her small market stall, in which she sells fresh food like matooke (green plantains, or a meal made when they are steamed). 

To help expand her business, Penina has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fresh food like matooke, sweet potatoes, and cassava for resale, and will help Penina to generate greater profits and pay for medical bills. Penina hopes that in the future she will be able to build a big house for herself and also start rearing animals like goats and cows.

Penina is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more fresh food like matooke, sweet potatoes, and cassava for resale.

loans.name: Mwendwa

texts.en:
Mwendwa is a resident of the Kongowea area of Coast Province, Kenya. He is married and owns a charcoal business that has been in operation for four years. He is also a sales agent who is paid on commission. 

Mwendwa learned about Milango Financial Services from a friend. He joined the organization with the goal of accessing credit to improve his business operations. His main challenges are the punitive measures enforced on charcoal sellers by the local authorities, and the lack of capital for expansion. This loan will allow him to gain capital to expand his business.

Mwendwa is applying for a loan of 10,650 Kenyan Shillings to purchase additional charcoal to sell. He will add the extra income from this loan to his savings in order to improve his family's living conditions. He aspires to be a wholesaler of charcoal in the future.

loans.use: to purchase additional charcoal to sell

loans.name: Doreen

texts.en:
Doreen is 22 years old and lives in the town of Kasese in the Fortportal region of Uganda. She is single and has two children who both attend school. For the past five years, Doreen has been working hard to manage her business of selling dry coffee. 

To help expand her business, Doreen has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more dry coffee to sell. This will help Doreen generate a greater profit, allowing her to pay school fees for her children. Doreen hopes that she will be able to buy a vehicle in the future. 

Doreen is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more dry coffee to sell

loans.name: Aquentor

texts.en:
Aquentor is 43 years old and lives in Kakata Town. She is married and has three children between the ages of six and sixteen. All of her children attend school and live at home.

For the past ten years, Aquentor has been involved in business; she currently sells bread in her community. One of her main challenges is the high price of  flour, sugar, and oil. Because she doesn't have enough income to meet her community's needs, she is requesting a loan to purchase flour, sugar, and oil to increase the number of customers she can serve. 

In the near future, Aquentor plans to build a house for her family and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase flour, sugar, and oil for her business

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is a married man with five children, two of whom are in higher institutions of learning. He has been doing various jobs including construction and agriculture to meet his household's needs. He sells plantains, which are a major delicacy to town dwellers, at affordable prices.

Charles would like the money to renovate his house to make it more habitable. He hopes he will be able to get another micro-mortgage loan to construct low income rental houses for those that cannot afford the high cost of living in the city. He is thankful that this product is so affordable and yet the period is long enough to give him time to find the money to pay back.

loans.use: to buy construction materials to renovate his house.

loans.name: Jane's Group

texts.en:
Jane's group is comprised of 4 hard working women.  Jane is 18 years old and lives in the town of Hima, in the Fort Portal region of Uganda.  For the past 2 years, Jane has been working hard to manage her small retail shop, which sells plastic materials that are used for plates.

To help expand her business, Jane has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to buy more plastic items such as cups and plates that will be sold in the shop.  This will help Jane to generate greater profits and to pay for her medical bills.  Jane hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land and to build a house. 

Jane is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides a safe place for young Ugandan women to participate in group activities, and provides a forum for life skills training.

loans.use: to buy more plastic items such as cups and plates that will be sold in her shop.

loans.name: Ta-Memsu Group

texts.en:
Hawa is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Hawa was born in Makeni City 35 years ago. She is married, and the couple has 3 children, 1 of whom is attending secondary school. 

For 5 years now, Hawa has been selling market food: palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), onions, margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), salt, pepper, tomatoes, etc. 

This is the first loan that Hawa and her group members have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Hawa will use her  share of the loan (500,000.00 Sierra Leonean Leones) to expand her business. She will buy palm oil, onions, margi, salt, pepper, tomatoes, etc. at wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to  buy palm oil, onions, margi, salt, pepper, tomatoes, etc. at wholesale to add to her current stock

loans.name: Jiguiya Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq membres du groupe    JIGUIYA   sont  des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans, et ont en moyenne  3 enfants. Elles vivent  dans des  familles monogamiques à Médine un des quartiers populaire de la ville de Sikasso 3ème  région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur douzième prêt avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.
Mme DJENEDJIE fait le commerce de grain de riz dans ce groupe de femmes de JIGUIYA elle se tient au milieu. 
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt 4 sacs de riz décortiqué qu’elle revend en détail sur place en famille à une clientèle composée pour la majeur partie de femmes au comptant. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35 000 FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne .
texts.en:
The five members of the JIGUIYA group are married women who, on average, are 35 years old and have three children each.  They live in monogamous families in Médine, one of the working class neighborhoods of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali).  This is their twelfth loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, and they are taking this loan to meet their customers' needs.

DJENEDJIE is a member of the JIGUIYA group and she sells rice.  In the photo, she is the woman standing in the middle.

She is planning to use her loan to buy four bags of hulled rice (brown rice) which she will resell locally, with her family, to a retail customer base which mostly consists of women who pay her cash.

She is expecting average monthly profits to reach 35,000 CFA francs, part of which will be used to pay back her loan and the interest, while the rest will be saved.

loans.use: to buy rice.

loans.name: Soutoura Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre  membres du groupe   SOUTOURA   sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 45 ans, et ont en moyenne  5 enfants. Elles vivent  dans des  familles monogames à Hamdallaye un des quartiers populaire de la ville de Sikasso. 
Elles sont à leur treizième prêt avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.
Mme Safiatou  fait le commerce  des habits  dans ce groupe de femmes  Soutoura et  elle se tient en deuxième position de la droite vers la gauche. 
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt une vingtaine de pièce de pagne wax qu’elle revendra en détail sur place en famille à une clientèle composée pour la majeur partie de femmes au comptant. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 85000 FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne .
texts.en:
The four members of the "Soutoura" group are married women, on average 45 years old with five children. They live in monogamous households in Hamdallaye, a populous district in the city of Sikasso.
They are on their 13th loan with the microfinance instituion Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy their customers' needs.
Ms. Safiatou runs a business selling clothes as part of the Soutoura group of women, and is standing second from the right in the photo. 
With her loan, she intends to buy twenty sets of pagne wax (a type of brightly-printed clothing), which she will resell at retail in cash in the area to a clientele composed mainly of women.
She foresees realizing an average monthly profit of 85,000 FCFA, of which one portion will be used to repay the loan and its interest, and the remainder will be saved.

loans.use: To buy clothes for resale.

loans.name: Djougousomperin Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe DJOUGOUSOMPERIN sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans, en moyenne  5 enfants et vivant dans des  familles monogamiques à Hamdallaye un des quartiers populaire de la ville de Sikasso 3ème  région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur treizième prêt avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.
Mme Kadiatou  fait le commerce  des tubercules dans ce groupe de femmes de  DJOUGOUSOMPERIN  elle se tient en première position de  la gauche vers la droite. 
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt une 20 sacs de 50 kg de pomme de terre qu’elle revend en détail sur place en famille à une clientèle composée pour la majeur partie de femmes au comptant. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 75.000FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne .
texts.en:
The four members of the "Djougousomperin" group are married women, on average 40 years old with five children, and live in monogamous households in Hamdallaye, a populous district in the city of Sikasso, the 3rd administrative region of Mali.
They are on their 13th loan with the microfinance instituion Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy their customers' needs.
Ms. Kadiatou runs a business selling tubers as part of the Djougousomperin group of women, and is standing all the way on the left in the photo.
With her loan, she intends to buy twenty 50-kg bags of potatoes, which she will resell at retail in cash in the area to a clientele composed mainly of women.
She foresees realizing an average monthly profit of 75,000 FCFA, of which one portion will be used to repay the loan and its interest, and the remainder will be saved.

loans.use: To buy and sell tubers.

loans.name: Morris

texts.en: Morris is 31 years old and lives in West Point, Liberia.  He is married and has a 5-year-old child that lives at home and attends school.  Morris is a high school graduate and has been running a grocery shop where he sells lappa (traditional clothing) for the past six years.  He has many customers and his daily sales are satisfactory, especially during the Christmas season.  He is requesting a loan to purchase more lappa.  He plans to expand his business and to build a store in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase more lappa (traditional clothing) for his business.

loans.name: Merab

texts.en:
Merab is 47 years old. He lives in the capital city of Tbilisi, with his wife and 18-year-old daughter. Several times, he has asked for loans from local financial institutions to start up a new business, without success. His loan requests were rejected each time because of the law income and lack of experience in his job, which is usually demanded by local credit providers.

The only source of the income for the family is the newly started business being run by Merab at the local open market. He has a store where different kinds of fruits and vegetables are sold.

Merab has requested a loan from Credo to develop his business trading in fruit and vegetables at the local open market. His loan request was approved as part of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program provides business start-ups and re-startups with credit, with soft conditions to the rural poor who do not have access to credit products, since they are regarded as “high-risk borrowers” because of their low income. 

With the received credit, Merab will purchase fruit and vegetables at wholesale prices and sell them in his open market store. Merab plans to increase the turnover in his trade business gradually. 

The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly increase the income of the family. Merab will work hard, and he will be able to improve the living conditions for his family. With this loan, family will generate enough income to access regular available credit products in the country’s capital market, in the event they need it.

loans.use: To purchase fruits and vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon is a resident of Kongowea area of Coast province, Kenya. He is married and owns a charcoal business that has been in operation for the last two years. He is also employed in the public transportation sector.

Simon learned about Milango Financial Services from a friend. He joined the organization with the goal of accessing credit to improve his business operations. His main challenges are the punitive measures enforced on charcoal sellers by the local authorities, and the lack of capital for expansion. This loan will allow him to gain capital to expand his business.

Simon is applying for a loan of 31,500 Kenyan Shillings to purchase additional charcoal to sell. He will add the extra income from this loan to his savings in order to improve his family's living conditions, as well as to pay for his child’s future school fees. He aspires to be a wholesaler of charcoal in the future.

loans.use: to purchase additional charcoal to sell

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a resident of the Kongowea area of Coast Province, Kenya. She is a married mother with two children who both attend school. Grace owns a grocery that she has been operating for five years. The family also receives some income from her husband’s employment.

Grace learned about Milango Financial Services from a friend, and joined the institution with the goal of accessing credit to improve her business operations.  She has been facing the challenge of limited capital for expansion.

Grace is applying for a loan of 21,050 Kenyan Shillings to purchase food items such as cereal, wheat flour, cooking oil, etc. The extra income from this loan will be added to her savings to improve her family's living conditions. She aspires to own other grocery stalls in the future and to pay for her children’s support with greater ease.

loans.use: to purchase food items such as cereal, wheat flour, cooking oil, etc.

loans.name: Barbra

texts.en:
Barbra is 16 years old and lives in the town of Hima in the Fortportal region of Uganda. For the past 6 months, Barbra has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells flour, sugar, soap, and cooking oil. 

To help expand her business, Barbra has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more commodities like sodas, sugar, splash juice and cooking oil for resale. This will help Barbra to generate greater profits, and pay for her medical expenses. 

Barbra hopes that in the future, she will be able to buy a plot of land and build a house. 

Barbra is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more commodities like sodas, sugar, splash juice and cooking oil for resale.

loans.name: Action Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the “Action” group from Makeni, a city in Northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, to apply for a loan of 500,000.00 Sierra Leonean Leones for each. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Sento is the leader of this group. The 25 year old is married to a house builder, and they have 2 children. Sento has been a businesswoman for 4 years, and she sells cooked rice with delicious sauce.  

With her share of this loan, she is going to buy cooking ingredients like uncooked rice, palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), tomatoes, onions, etc. in bulk.  With these items at hand, she will be able to cook a larger quantity of rice and sauce for sale.

loans.use: to buy cooking ingredients like uncooked rice, palm oil, tomatoes, onions, etc. in bulk.  With these items at hand, she will be able to cook a larger quantity of rice and sauce for sale.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria is a 30-year-old, single mother living in West Point, Liberia.  She has three children between the ages of 1 and 12.  They are not attending school due to the lack of financial support.  She has a table at the community market where she has been selling pig feet and spare ribs for the past six years.  Victoria makes a profit with each sale that she uses to buy more goods and to address the needs of her children.   She is requesting a loan to purchase more spare ribs and pig feet for the business.  Her future plan is to educate her children and become a businesswoman.

loans.use: to purchase more spare ribs and pig feet.

loans.name: Las Responsables 1, 2 & 4 Group

texts.en:
Celia is one of the members of the group Las Responsables (The Responsible Ones) 1, 2 & 4. She lives in a simple structure with her four children and their father. She is a hard-working and dedicated woman who works to help her family by bringing in extra income. 

Celia is excited to be taking her seventh loan with Esperanza, after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She has had her business for about nine years, starting off with her own savings after working in different jobs. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by all different styles of shoes, for women, men and kids. She sells her shoes door-to-door, and also from her home. 

Celia will use the profits to reinvest in her business, and to provide for her family's needs. She is helping her long-term partner by bringing extra income. Celia would like to thank you for your support.

loans.use: to buy new shoes for resale

loans.name: Adama

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 35-year-old Adama from southern Kulanda town in Bo. She is married with three children between the ages of 5 and 12 years. Her children are all currently attending school. 

To earn a living, Adama has been running a clothing business for 5 years. She works at her business every day, 8 hours per day. She began this business to raise income to support her family, and says that her business is doing well - since she started trading, she has never had a loss. 

Adama has asked for this loan to buy more material to make clothes with. The extra income from this loan will allow her to pay her childrens' school fees and increase her business. In the future, she hopes to operate an international business. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to buy more material to make clothes with

loans.name: Aminata

texts.en:
This is 25-year-old Aminata from southern Kulanda town Bo. She is married, with two children aged 3 and 7 years old.

Aminata runs a general business; she sells cocoa, sugar, milk and pure water. She has been running this business for the past four years. She lives in the shop room with her family.  She says that the main challenge for her business is low purchasing power of her customers.

Aminata has asked for a loan to buy different products like cocoa, sugar, milk and pure water. The extra income from this loan will allow her to grow her business, and buy a plot of land. In the future, she wants to build a permanent home for her family. Aminata appreciates your support.

loans.use: to buy different products like cocoa, sugar, milk and pure water

loans.name: Sanouya Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre  membres du groupe SANOUYA sont  essentiellement des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 41 ans, et ont en moyenne  4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogames au quartier Babemba un des nouveaux quartiers de la ville de Sikasso 3ème  région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.
Mme Aby fait le commerce de tissu dans ce groupe de femmes de SANOUYA elle se tient en deuxième position de  la gauche vers la droite. 
Elle compte acheter avec son prêt 7 pièces de tissus qu’elle revend en détail sur place. La clientèle est composé d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 26 000 FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne .
texts.en:
The four members of the "Sanouya" group are mainly married women, on average 41 years old with four children. They live mostly in monogamous households in the Babemba district, one of the new areas in the city of Sikasso, the 3rd administrative region of Mali.
They are on their second loan with the microfinance instituion Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy their customers' needs.
Ms. Aby runs a business selling fabric as part of the Sanouya group of women, and is standing second from the left in the photo.
With her loan, she intends to buy seven bolts of fabric, which she will resell at retail in the area. Her clientele is composed of men and women.
She foresees realizing an average monthly profit of 26,000 FCFA, of which one portion will be used to repay the loan and its interest, and the remainder will be saved.

loans.use: To buy fabric.

loans.name: Denbagnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe  DENBAGNOUMA  sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans, et ont en moyenne  5 enfants. Elles vivent dans des  familles monogamiques au quartier Babemba un des nouveaux quartiers de la ville de Sikasso 3ème  région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.
Mme Aby fait la restauration dans ce groupe de femmes de   DENBAGNOUMA  elle se tient en deuxième position de  la gauche vers la droite. 
Elle compte acheter avec son prêt 1 sac de riz et le reste sera utilisé dans l’achat des condiments. La majeur partie de sa clientèle est composée d’hommes. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 20.500FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne .
Elle ambitionne d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
The four members of the "Denbagnouma" group are married women, on average 39 years old with five children. They live in monogamous households in the Babemba district, one of the new areas in the city of Sikasso, the 3rd administrative region of Mali.
They are on their second loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy their customers' needs.
Ms. Aby prepares and sells meals as part of the Denbagnouma group of women, and is standing second from the left in the photo.
With her loan, she intends to buy one sack of rice and to use the remainder to buy condiments.The majority of her customers are men.
She foresees realizing an average monthly profit of 20,500 FCFA, of which one portion will be used to repay the loan and its interest, and the remainder will be saved.
Her ambition is to increase her sales volume in order to better satisfy her clientele.

loans.use: To buy ingredients to prepare and sell meals.

loans.name: Faïda Group

texts.fr:
Les 7 membres du groupe FAÏDA sont essentiellement de femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 36 ans, en moyenne  4 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles monogames à Hamdallaye un des quartiers populaire de la ville de Sikasso. 
Elles sont à leur troisième prêt avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.
Mme  MARIAM  fait le commerce  des pagnes wax dans ce groupe de femmes de  FAÏDA elle se tient debout au milieu. 
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt environs 5 pièces de pagne qu’elle revend en détail sur place en famille à une clientèle composée pour la majeur partie de femmes au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 22.500 FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne .
texts.en:
The seven members of the "Faïda" group are mainly married women, on average 36 years old with four children, and live mostly in monogamous households in Hamdallaye, a populous district in the city of Sikasso.
They are on their third loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy their customers' needs.
Ms. Mariam runs a business selling pagnes wax (a type of brightly-printed clothing) as part of the Faïda group of women, and is standing in the middle in the photo.
With her loan, she intends to buy about five sets of pagnes wax, which she will resell at retail in cash in the area to a clientele composed mainly of women.
She foresees realizing an average monthly profit of 22,500 FCFA, of which one portion will be used to repay the loan and its interest, and the remainder will be saved.

loans.use: To buy and sell clothing.

loans.name: Nani

texts.en: Nani is a 45-year-old woman from the small village of Mtskheta.  She lives with her 19 and 22-year-old sons.  Nani is involved in agricultural activities, including two milk cows for cheese production.  She sells cheese locally in an open market at a good price.  She is a very hard working woman and has a rich experience in her business.  Nani requested a loan for purchasing feed for the cattle.  After feeding, the cows will be fattened properly and she will be able to sell them at a good price in the spring.  It will increase the income of the family and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase cattle feed.

loans.name: Bridget

texts.en:
